raw_text:
Hacker threat to Apple's iTunes
 
 Users of Apple's music jukebox iTunes need to update the software to avoid a potential security threat.
 
 Hackers can build malicious playlist files which could crash the program and let them seize control of the computer by inserting Trojan code. A new version of iTunes is now available from the Apple website which solves the problem. Security firm iDefence, which notified users of the problem, recommended that users upgrade to iTunes version 4.7.1. The problem affects all users of iTunes - Windows and Mac OS - running versions 4.7 and earlier. Users can automatically upgrade iTunes by opening the "look for updates" window in the program. The security firm says users should avoid clicking on or accessing playlist files - which have the file extension of .pls or .m3u - which have come from unknown sources. Itunes is the world's most popular online music store with more than 200 million songs downloaded since it launched in 2003.
llama3.2:1b: Apple has released a new version of iTunes, version 4.7.1, to address a security threat that hackers can exploit by building malicious playlist files and crashing the program. The updated software requires users to update from versions 4.7 or earlier. Users should avoid downloading .pls or .m3u files from unknown sources, which contain malicious code.

A new version is available on the Apple website, recommended by iDefence for users running versions 4.7 and earlier on Windows or Mac OS.

There's a new version of iTunes available from the Apple site that solves this issue, and iDefence recommended updating to version 4.7.1. They also mention that this problem affects all users running versions 4.7 and earlier on both Windows and Mac OS. Users can automatically upgrade by opening the "look for updates" window in iTunes. The security firm advises avoiding clicking on or accessing .pls or .m3u files because they come from unknown sources. Additionally, it's noted that iTunes is a huge online music store with over 200 million downloads since 2003.

Hacker threats threaten Apple's iTunes by creating malicious playlists that crash programs or steal control. The latest iTunes version addresses this issue, updated from 4.7 onwards. Users are advised to upgrade to version 4.7.1 via "look for updates." To avoid accessing unknown playlist files ending with .pls or .m3u, users should avoid clicking on them. iTunes, widely popular since 2003 with over 200 million downloads, remains the most downloaded music platform worldwide.
